title: Corporate mentors are a gift to charities
text:
Vicki is very capable and she’s done a really good job. Now she’s trying to build her profile and ability to go to more schools and counsel more children, so we talk about those sorts of things. Usually she’s got the answer – I just ask questions. I think the art of good coaching is more about helping a person think something through, because at the end of the day they have to own the solution.

There has been a bit of reverse mentoring. Mental health in children is such a big issue, and when you hear Vicki talk about it, you can’t help but be quite moved by the challenge.

Vicki Condon was motivated to set up Raise after the teenage son of a family friend took his own life. Wolter Peeters

I’ve also been really inspired. She’s set up this office, she’s hired hundreds of people who are on contracts, she started it all herself. I have watched her in the way that she has resolutely continued to take her message to politicians, to schools, and her tenacity and commitment are second to none. I think that’s probably been the biggest learning for me.

Kilfinan does a review every year about how the mentoring relationship is going, just to make sure both sides see it as valuable. At the two-year mark, there’s usually a decision about whether we continue or not. Vicki and I have decided to keep going.

Vicki Condon

My background was in corporate human resource management and when I had my children, I decided I didn’t want to work corporate hours any more. So I retrained as a counsellor and found a couple of mentoring organisations that I volunteered with.

I could see things that I might do a little bit differently. So I started writing a business plan and thought, “If I were to run my own youth mentoring organisation, this is how it would look.”

Then I put the plan away in my bottom drawer because I thought we have so many charities in Australia, we don’t need another not-for-profit. And what do I know about running a charity?

A few months later, our family experienced the death by suicide of a family friend’s 14-year-old son. The day after his funeral I pulled out the business plan because I thought if I could help one young person like him, it would be worth having a go. That was November 2008. The organisation was just me in my bedroom office for the first three years.

Advertisement

We attract volunteers from the community who are trained by qualified counsellors. We’ve trained 4500 volunteer mentors, and worked with 5500 young people.

I received an email from Kilfinan about applying for a mentor and I thought it was an amazing idea.

The application process was quite long, but it helped me to really get clear in my mind what I could get from having a mentor.

Raise was working on this big strategic plan to offer our program to every public secondary school in the country. That’s 1036 schools, meaning we’d grow from 100 schools to more than 1000. That means 15,000 mentors.

I knew I needed help and I was really keen to get some neutral advice with the growth strategy, some support around how to manage our board, and some leadership development.

One of David's greatest gifts is asking, “Are you OK? How are you going?” — Vicki Condon, CEO of Raise Foundation

It was a bit daunting in the beginning because I thought I didn’t deserve this kind of help, but David just treats me as an equal.

I meet him four or five times a year. We’re quite casual. I email and say, “OK, when can we get together?” He’s always very gracious in terms of fitting me into his diary – he’s obviously very busy. He’s the ultimate teacher – just by sitting alongside him, I learn so much.

David has helped me to identify what kind of leader I want to be. I want to be democratic in terms of involving everybody, but I have learnt that I need to develop some courage in my leadership, because I’ve always been the doer. Now I need to let everyone else use their skills and I need to stand back. So he’s helped me to see that I can trust in the team.

The one thing I hate about my job is doing the media and having to present. But David says, “Vicki, they’re just people like all of us.” I had to pitch to the education minister in Canberra, and David said: “He’s just a person, he believes in education. You’ve got a good program.”

He just instils a quiet confidence. One of his greatest gifts is asking, “Are you OK? How are you going?” As CEO, I am forever spending time with the team, partners, the mentees and volunteer mentors. And I’m always asking, “How are you going?” David is the only one who ever asks me how I’m going.

A lot of not-for-profit organisations are born out of compassion or wanting to do something for the community, but they don’t really have the corporate expertise to run effectively. Kilfinan means we can learn skills for free from extraordinary business leaders, which means we can have much more impact.
description: Former Telstra chief David Thodey has been inspired by his work with Vicki Condon, CEO of student welfare not-for-profit Raise Foundation.
